The team adventure challenge that pushes you from dawn to dusk. Ride, hike and kayak to beat the sunset. Run for something bigger. Find charity places in everything from fun runs to ultra runs, back a cause you love, and turn every mile into real impact. Charity runs give you more than a finish line: they give your training purpose. From local 5Ks to iconic sell-out races, you can secure a charity place and join a team that keeps you motivated from sign-up to race day.   Charity places are guaranteed places in events allocated by charities for popular events. Instead of buying a place directly from the organiser, you apply to a charity, commit to a minimum fundraising target, and, in return, you receive a guaranteed place in the event, along with a support package that makes the whole journey easier and more sociable. Here‚Äôs the simple flow. Pick a distance and date you can genuinely commit to. A realistic plan beats a dramatic one every time ‚Äî and it makes fundraising far easier because people can feel you‚Äôre going to follow through. The same event can come with very different charity offers. Before you apply, check: If you‚Äôre choosing between two charities, pick the one you can explain confidently in one sentence. When your 'why' is clear, asking for donations feels natural, not awkward. Most charities ask a few quick questions about your motivation and how you‚Äôll fundraise. Keep it practical: who you‚Äôll ask first, what you‚Äôll do for a boost, and how you‚Äôll keep momentum. Apply early for big-name events ‚Äî charity allocations can fill fast. Fundraising is nothing to worry about - you'll see plenty of fundraisers across the website who are well on their way to hitting their target plus you'll get plenty of support from your chosen charity. You don‚Äôt need a million ideas, you just need a few that work well: Want quick boosters? Ask your employer about matched giving, run a small quiz night or bake sale, and turn long runs into 'sponsor my miles' updates. Bottom line: choose an event you‚Äôll enjoy training for, pick a charity you truly care about, and start fundraising early. You‚Äôll run stronger, raise more, and cross the line knowing every mile meant something. Want to read more? Read the   from our blog. Got questions?  . Big-name events with charity places. The route is displayed on the  The Loch Ness Marathon follows a spectacular point-to-point route alongside world-famous Loch Ness, starting in an atmospheric moorland setting and continuing through stunning Highland scenery, taking you along the south-eastern shores of Loch Ness, across the River Ness, to finish in Inverness, capital city of the Highlands. The Loch Ness Marathon is a running event and all runners are welcome. The aim is to support every participant, whatever their pace, from start to finish and provide the best possible experience. The Marathon starts at 10.00 and the race cut-off time is 7 hours at 17.00. In the interests of safety and to minimise the disruption to the local community and residents, roads along the final 3 miles in Inverness start to re-open from 16.30 and the finish line and Event Village start to be dismantled from 17.00. If you think that you will take longer than 6hr 30min, you are asked to use the pavement through Inverness. Participants still on the course after the cut-off time continue at their own risk. Being well hydrated and drinking little and often is essential for achieving your best performance. There are seven water stations along the marathon course, water will be provided in 330ml recyclable plastic bottles with sports caps. There will be four gel stations along the marathon route providing High5 Energy Gels. Whether the Robin Hood Half Marathon is your first or fiftieth half marathon, you'll need to train for it. Your charity may offer a free in-depth training plan with guidance. When you head to the start line on the big day, people will be able to see clearly which charity you're supporting - a great conversation-starter for solo runners! When you're partway through your half marathon and your energy is flagging, what you need is a boost from cheering spectators to keep you moving. raw.desc_preview: The route starts and finishes just outside Edinburgh at Musselburgh Racecourse. The Scottish 10K route is seriously fast and flat! You'll run out and back along the magnificent Golf Coast before...
raw.full_description: The route starts and finishes just outside Edinburgh at Musselburgh Racecourse. The Scottish 10K route is seriously fast and flat! You'll run out and back along the magnificent Golf Coast before finishing in the final furlong at Musselburgh Racecourse; Scotland's oldest racecourse. Come and be part of it! This event has a strict maximum cut off time of 1 hour 30 minutes (from when the back of the race crosses the start line) for all participants. The 10K is a serious athletics endurance race which requires a large amount of appropriate training and preparation in order to complete it safely. Therefore participants who do not intend to complete the course within this time limit are discouraged from entering. The finish is in front of the grandstand at the racecourse which was really nice. At the end you were presented with your medal plus t-shirt, foil blanket, yoghurt bar, energy drink sachet and a bottle of water. Your bib number included what size of t-shirt you had requested so this should guarantee everyone got the right size. The medal detaches so can be used as a key ring. At the start there was no formal warm up so the atmosphere was a little flat, but pretty good overall. I would happily do this race again.                                  Turn2us is a national charity that provides practical information and support to people facing financial shocks. We work with those who have experienced not having enough money to live on to develop practical information and support that helps people cope with life-changing events.

Piccadilly Piccadilly London Greater London W1J UK Every year thousands of runners take part in this event and fundraise for charity. While this is hugely beneficial to the charities it gives the runner advantages too, from supporting a cause that is close to your heart to securing a place in this highly sought-after event and much more. Committing to raising money for charity gives you motivation to get outside and run, plus all of these extras which will elevate your event experience: Charities know that raising money is all part of the challenge, which is why they provide advice, branded materials and a personalised online fundraising page to help the donations roll in. Think videos for social media, branded imagery and testimonials from previous runners. Whether this is your first run or your fifth, you'll need to train for it! You'll receive an in-depth training plan with guidance, plus many charities have access to expert coaches and elite runners too, who can provide exclusive tips for your race preparation. When you show up on the day, people need to be able to see clearly that you're supporting a charity. Most charities will give you a branded and personalised t-shirt or vest to run in on the big day, and often a training top too. When you're partway through your run and your energy is flagging, what you need is a boost from cheering spectators to keep you moving. Many charities set up a cheer station along the route, keeping an eye out for you to send up a huge cheer as you run past! Refreshments and an indulgent post-race sports massage are often provided by charities for their runners. This is the perfect way to recover alongside other people who have run for that cause. You won't be the only person running for that charity, so it's well worth meeting other runners through the charity's invite-only social media pages! You can organise to meet up for training runs, chat with the charity's expert coaches and share tips and stories with each other to keep the motivation levels running high. Build marathon confidence on a fully supported long run, choosing your distance, fuelling every lap and training smart in a relaxed, friendly environment with likeminded runners. Trail running offers a different kind of challenge to road racing, combining varied terrain, changing conditions and inspiring landscapes. Routes often follow footpaths, bridleways, forest tracks and coastal trails, rewarding runners with scenery as well as a strong sense of adventure. Trail runs come in many formats, from short, accessible events ideal for first-timers to longer, more technical routes for experienced off-road runners. Some focus on steady climbs and descents, while others wind through parks, woods and open countryside. Answers to the most common questions about trail runs and trail running. A trail run takes place mainly on off-road paths such as woodland trails, footpaths, bridleways or countryside tracks rather than roads or pavements. Yes ‚Äî many trail runs are beginner-friendly, especially shorter distances on well-marked paths with gentle terrain. Trail runs involve varied terrain, elevation changes and natural surfaces, making them less predictable but often more scenic than road races. Trail running shoes offer better grip and protection on uneven ground, though there are some easier  , depending on the conditions. Most organised trail runs are timed, though some focus more on participation and experience than finishing position. Yes ‚Äî some trail runs extend into ultra-distance territory. raw.title: Stockport Trail Half Marathon
raw.desc_preview: This popular half marathon trail race takes place along the picturesque Middlewood Way and Macclesfield Canal and is now in its 12th year.
raw.full_description: This popular half marathon trail race takes place along the picturesque Middlewood Way and Macclesfield Canal and is now in its 12th year. Great from start to finish which includes the booking itself through to communication, the parking, brief, the actual race and the goodies at the end. Organiser were very supportive throughout. Would highly recommend to those looking for a PB on a virtually flat route on the trails or even those new to running the half distance. Mark T Always friendly and well organised. Good atmosphere. Great to have baggage van right at the finish. Rhona J The pre-race briefing emails were so informative - literally no query was left unanswered! This alone was a huge help and set the tone for race day, which was equally as organised and efficient. Great course, good mix of gorgeous scenery to take your mind off the distance, and fab support from fellow runners and marshals along the way. A really enjoyable morning, and a new firm favourite in my race calendar. (The delicious flapjacks were an added bonus!) Cara B This race has been running for several years now and is fast becoming a staple in the pre-spring marathon calendar. It‚Äôs a low cost and extremely well organised event from a small but dedicated local organiser. The route covers the Middlewood Way and Macclesfield Canal between Marple and Whiteley Green (and back again), with spectacular scenery and views up in to Lyme Park. The course is essentially flat, with a slight incline in the first half but, of course, that turns into a slight descent on the homeward leg. As a trail race, the route is very sensitive to the conditions, but the MWW is usually in a good state, but the canal towpath is more prone to mud. Road shoes on a good day, consider trail shoes if the canal is particularly bad! Matt D Absolutely fantastic event. Highly recommend it. Really good value for money. Great organisation - i think they underestimated the number of toilets needed hence the race started late - but registration was a breeze. Marshalls were really friendly and great flapjacks atbthe end for refuelling. The course is very flat. The stretch along the canal is really pretty. This is my secknd race organised by Crazy legs and i will be booking more. Rebecca B This was my first trail half and I loved it. Sam L A fantastic event, with such friendly marshals. A lovely route and well organised throughout. Thank you to all who helped, and special thanks to Beth, Mike and Dave for their support and encouragement. Denise O Fast and flat. Friendly marshals. Well organised start in waves which meant no congestion. Maria S This event was brilliant ! Really well organised and the people helping out were great :) Jassica S A huge and heartfelt thanks to all involved - it was a wonderfully welcoming race and blessed with glorious dry weather (and a bit of sun!). Special thanks to Mike, Dave and Beth who helped us with their positive encouragement and support. Ride, hike and kayak to beat the sunset. 42 miles of footpath meandering through the historic countryside of Essex in an easterly direction towards the coast, along an ancient pilgrimage route dating back to the 7th century! 08:30 Age 18 & over ¬£60 The St Peter‚Äôs Way is 42 miles of footpath meandering through the historic countryside of Essex in an easterly direction towards the coast, from Chipping Ongar to the ancient chapel of St Peter-on-the-Wall at Bradwell on Sea. An ancient pilgrimage route dating back to the 7th century littered with historic churches and scenic countryside. Some sections of which are listed in the Doomsday Book from 1085. It‚Äôs an absolute staple on the winter ultra scene. Matt J Anyone entering this event should ideally have completed at least one marathon distance race previously and although it is not enforced, this is a good benchmark. If you can run a marathon in around 6-7 hours you should be able to complete this event. A mandatory kit list is readily available. The route is a mixture of muddy trails, fields and rural tracks and roads with the final section being on raised sea wall. It can be very exposed in places and if wet, can be very muddy. There are some hills but it's mostly rolling countryside and very runnable. The last few miles to the finish can be cold, wet and windy. There are 4 outdoor checkpoints along the way. Each will be stocked with similar food, coke, water, squash, sweet and savory foods including vegan and veggie options. If you have specific dietary needs please be sure to list them when you enter. There will be nuts and nut based products handled at checkpoints. Cut off time 11am - approximately 7.9 miles total (2 hours 30 mins) Cut off time 13:15pm - approximately 15.8 miles total (4 hours 45 mins) Cut off time 4pm - approximately 25.4 miles total (7 hours 30 mins) Cut off time 7pm - approximately 34 miles total (10 hours 30 mins) Finish Cut Off time 9pm - approximately 43 miles total (12.5 hours) The Pleasance 229 High Street Chipping Ongar Ongar Essex CM5 9AB UK Registration is in the Budworth Hall, opposite the start car park. ¬£15pp. You have the option to book a minibus back to the start from the finish. The buses will leave at the following times on a first finished first served basis 3:30pm, 6pm and 8:30pm. Anyone finished after 8:30pm will be transported by race staff back to the start. ¬£6-¬£10 per day. You can leave your car in the public car park at the start location for a small fee on a Sunday. Excellent, mainly trail, run, thoroughly enjoyed it! Kerry M Excellent organisation and incredible value for money. Super well organised race along a lovely mostly countryside route. You have to be relatively self sufficient for navigation, but with a smart watch that can take a GPX file that‚Äôs not really a problem. Highly recommend. Kevin LV Great off-road, muddy race. Well-organised informal ultra, providing great support for all levels. Jon P Great organisation. Lovely trail course. Friendly atmosphere. Marshals were great! Would recommend downloading the GPX route file onto your running device, as will be needed for some sections. You are likely to get muddy! Adam W Well organised, friendly and well-considered ultra trail. Super organisation, brilliant volunteers & awesome atmosphere and comradery within the running packs! Tom S Excellent. First time doing this event and it was everything I hoped it would be. Superb organisation, mud, friendly aid stations, mud, impromptu cuppa at the last stations that got me to the end, more mud and finally the disco lights guiding us home in the dark along the sea wall. Jona D Great race! Really well organised, great volunteers, would highly recommend! Peter B Really friendly, low key, well organised race along a beautiful course that is not to be underestimated - that mud was tough and I think it was relatively dry this year! David A So well organised, all volunteers so friendly/encouraging, great route. First time of doing anything over a marathon distance and absolutely loved it. Will definitely enter next year. Thank you to everyone involved x Laura P It‚Äôs an absolute staple on the Winter ultra scene. Matt J Reviews thanks to RaceCheck Entry fee ¬£60.00 Add the event to your shortlist to make it easy to find again. raw.title: Running Tribe Races | Feb
raw.desc_preview: Don‚Äôt start another race feeling under pressure. Sign up for a Running Tribe event today, relax and run your own race.
raw.full_description: Don‚Äôt start another race feeling under pressure. Sign up for a Running Tribe event today, relax and run your own race. Don‚Äôt start another race feeling under pressure. Sign up for a Running Tribe event today, relax and run your own race. Step 1 | Enter Choose your distance Step 1 | Enter Choose your distance Running Tribe events were borne out of the frustrations of founder Steve who, after completing 77 miles over 23 hours ended up walking away with nothing to show for his efforts after succumbing to an old injury. Running Tribe events are a bit different. Race training can be relentless but necessary to perform your very best on the day. You know you run better relaxed but sleep, nutrition and even that niggling injury all have to be in check too! In truth, there‚Äôs a lot that can get in the way of you finishing your full race distance. And when that happens, it‚Äôs gutting. Worse still, the distance you do manage to cover doesn‚Äôt count for anything. No medal, no congrats. Just the shame of handing over your number and slipping back to the car park empty-handed. Running Tribe thinks that‚Äôs wrong and are changing it, one race at a time. Running Tribe courses are circular routes of a minimum of 10.6k and you can attempt as many loops as you feel able to on the day. You‚Äôll have one of the best-stocked aid stations on the events circuit, packed with everything from baked goodies to energy gels and, as your kit bag will always within reasonable reach you can use your pitstop to test out different fuelling techniques and running gear along the way. The Emmott Arms Town Street Rawdon Leeds West Yorkshire LS19 6PP UK Lovely route, well marked, an enjoyable run. Teresa W Tough but enjoyable inaugural event. When you come up across the field and through the gate at the top (near the end) once we went over the brow it wasn't clear where to go. We went the wrong way first, then realised, then saw a pink arrow...but it could have done with another marker up there. Hope that makes sense. Otherwise, BRILLIANT, thanks so much. The team adventure challenge that pushes you from dawn to dusk. Ride, hike and kayak to beat the sunset. A 48-mile route through historical Suffolk and Norfolk, starting from Knettishall Heath Nature reserve and running north to Holme-next-the-Sea on the Norfolk Coast. 08:30 Age 18 & over ¬£60 It has existed on maps, and as a known route, through recorded history in the UK, with the Romans paving sections and modernising it. It's a mix of straight tracks, bridleways, footpaths and quiet country roads and is relatively flat and easy to navigate. It's well marked with local signage on finger posts and National Trail Acorn markings. You will also have a detailed GPS file to use on any device. With a generous 12 hours to complete the run its a great run for all running abilities and a good entry level event for beginner ultra runners. Two outdoor and two indoor checkpoints with a shuttle bus provided from the finish car park to the start as an option for those who want to leave their car at the finish. First aid cover for your safety and GPS tracking allows friends and family to follow you. Bespoke wooden medal and the option of a quality custom T-Shirt and Buff as additional purchase items. A mandatory kit list is readily available. The route is displayed on the  The route is a mix of footpaths, bridleways, rural lanes with a few small off road sections and is mostly good underfoot. The boardwalk section in the first few miles can be slippery or even underwater in cold or wet weather. There are two versions of the route; one with the 2-mile extra diversion and one without. You will hear on the day if runners are doing the wet diversion or not and the cut offs would be extended by 30 minutes if so. There are 3 checkpoints along the route at regular intervals and a finish checkpoint. No facilities. Only basic cold drinks and snacks. Cut-off time - leave CP by 12:00. Cold foods and snacks, hot drinks, toilets. Cut-off time - leave CP by 15:15. Cut-off time - leave CP by 17:00. Hot food, hot drinks, changing, toilets, end of race bag. Finish cut-off 20:30. You need an average of 4mph or 15 minute mile pace or better to stay inside the cut offs. If the diversion is in place, these are all 30 mins later. Knettishall Heath Nature Reserve, SSSI and GSI site Knettishall Thetford Suffolk IP22 2TQ UK The postcode gets you to the nearest farmhouse about 750m away, best to search for the nature reserve on google/apple maps. The recommendation is to park at the finish then get the event bus to the start. There is a local pay and display car park in Holme (6ft/2m height restriction). ¬£15pp The bus will pick you up from the road beside the car park at 5:50am prompt and there will be a member of staff helping.  The car park at the start is pay and display but is free until 10am, so anyone being dropped off should be fine however, it shuts in the evening and you can't park overnight. Lovely flat (ish) simple no frills race. As a back of the packer I really enjoyed this event. Definitely one for runners though, not walkers. Laura M Lovely event, brilliantly organised. Flat as a pancake and easy running. An ultra for all -- complete your fastest or first ultra. Excellent all-round event. Very similar to previous years, a good transition to new organisers, warm and friendly staff, first class. Boris M Tougher than it looks. Great mid-distance ultra race under the big skys of Norfolk, not that challenging on paper but tough nonetheless. Pretty straight-forward navigation and great organisation and support. Adam W-T Loved it. Great for an "ultra casual" like me - nice terrain, easy navigation, good logistics, nice people. Simon B Amazing scenery, excellent crew and volunteers, loads of fun! Everyone at the check points was so nice and helpful. Really enjoyed my day out! I was a little grumpy in the middle as I had not realised how much was on road, but that is the Peddars Way so not much the RD can do about that. I may bring a change of shoes if I do it again... Andrew G Nice ultra - well run. Shane M Reviews thanks to Racecheck Entry fee ¬£60.00 Add the event to your shortlist to make it easy to find again. raw.title: Bedgebury Forest 10 and 5 Mile
raw.desc_preview: A stunning race beneath the majestic pines at Bedgebury!
raw.full_description: A stunning race beneath the majestic pines at Bedgebury! A stunning race beneath the majestic pines at Bedgebury! There will be parking on site. Please follow signs to your designated distance car park. 10 mile runners will be parking within the Walled Garden with 5 mile entrants parking in the main car park. The area is also accessible by bicycle. Bedgebury National Pinetum and Forest is just off the A21 in Kent. The race is best accessed by car and your entry fee includes vehicle admission charges. I must also add that the marshalls were excellent. Always happy and cheering despite having to stand in the cold. Would I recommend this race? Yes. Would I do it again? Definitely. Last word - wear trail shoes! Mark R The marshalls were well located throughout the course and were really encouraging, and remarkably upbeat considering how cold they must have been. WellChild helps them to be cared for at home rather than in hospital by their WellChild Nurses and Helping Hands home improvement initiative which transforms gardens and bedrooms. ¬£25 raised can pay for an hour's nurse care and ¬£500 can fund a week's research to help children with serious brain injury.

From the edge of Vesterbro to the calm of √òsterbro, from the pulse of the inner city to the water along the harbourfront, every neighbourhood adds its own rhythm to your run. It‚Äôs a course where landmarks meet lactic acid. Where history and heartbeat merge into 42.2 kilometres of pure motion. You pass the Lakes, Amalienborg Palace, the Marble Church. You feel the roar on Dronning Louises Bridge, the echo through the narrow city streets, and that feeling of freedom as you reach colourful Christianshavn, cross Langebro, and hit Islands Brygge ‚Äî with the city skyline rising ahead of you. 6 hours. According to an analysis by RunRepeat, the average male pace for marathons is 6:43 mins/km and the average female pace is 7:26 mins/km but these averages mask variations between ages. The State of Running 2019 report by RunRepeat and the IAAF analysed 107.9 million race results from 70,000+ events between 1986 - 2018 and concluded that runners have never been slower - male runners in particular.¬† In 1986 the average finish time for a marathon was 3:52:35 but by 2019 it was 4:32:49 - 40 minutes and 14 seconds slower. This is partially explained by the fact that runners are also getting older but gender also plays a role. Both men and women got quite a lot slower between 1986 - 2001 but since then, men have continued to get slower (at a slower rate) whereas women have actually started to get faster - knocking 4 minutes off the average marathon time since 2001. The average marathon pace at the time of the report was 6:43 mins/km for a male and 7:26 mins/km for a female. In terms of age, 30-50 year olds have the best average finishing time at 4:24 hours; under 30's average 4:32 and 50-60 year olds average 4:34 - so younger isn't always better. Over 70's are consistently slower at 5 hours 40 minutes. For more detailed statistics, please refer to the  . Most runners need   of consistent training, depending on current fitness and goals. If you‚Äôre newer to running or aiming for a big PB, allow longer and build up gradually to avoid injury. Look for marathons with  . When it comes to marathons, there are few events as renowned as the World Marathon Majors. Also known as the Abbott World Marathon Majors, the WMM is a series of six of the world's most prestigious marathons - Tokyo Marathon, Boston Marathon, London Marathon, Berlin Marathon, Chicago Marathon and New York City Marathon. Each marathon has its own unique features, making them a must-run for marathoners worldwide. From the vibrant streets of Tokyo to the historic course of Boston, the iconic landmarks of London, the autumn scenery of Berlin, the diverse neighborhoods of Chicago, and the triumphant finish line in New York City's Central Park - each one of the marathons has something different to offer. The Tokyo Marathon, held in the bustling capital of Japan, takes place in late February or early March, showcasing the beauty of Japan's capital to runners from around the world. With its festive atmosphere, enthusiastic spectators, and a course that blends traditional and modern city sights, the Tokyo Marathon offers an unforgettable experience for both elite runners and amateur athletes alike. The Boston Marathon, running since 1897, is the world's oldest annual marathon and holds a special place in marathon running history. The marathon is famous for its challenging 'Heartbreak Hill' and attracts elite runners from around the world but be warned, you might need some of that marathon endurance and spirit as it is notoriously difficult to secure a place. London Marathon, held in April, offers runners a truly a world-class event racing by iconic landmarks whilst experiencing the vibrant atmosphere and thousands of cheering spectators. Not only does it attract elite athletes but it also provides everyday runners - many in fancy dress - with the chance to participate. Berlin Marathon, held in September, is known for its flat and fast course, making it a favourite among runners aiming to achieve personal bests. Runners from all over the world flock to Berlin to experience the city's rich history, vibrant culture, and stunning autumn scenery. Chicago Marathon, which takes place in October, showcases the hospitality and energy of the city of Chicago. With its scenic tour of diverse neighborhoods, runners get to experience the rich cultural tapestry that makes up the city. The marathon, sponsored by the Bank of America, attracts runners of all levels, creating an atmosphere of camaraderie and support throughout the race. As runners cross the finish line in Grant Park, they celebrate the completion of an incredible journey. New York City Marathon, held in November, is the largest marathon in the world with over 50,000 runners taking to the streets of the five New York boroughs. The marathon's finish line in Central Park is a truly triumphant moment for every finisher. The World Marathon Majors operates a unique scoring system that takes into account finishers, podium placings, and age group rankings to determine the winners. Runners earn points based on their performance in each of the marathons. Becoming a Six Star Finisher is the ultimate achievement for marathon runners. To earn this accolade, runners must successfully complete all six marathons of the World Marathon Majors series. Once accomplished, runners join an elite group of athletes and are awarded the coveted Six Star Finisher medal. Crossing the finish line of the final marathon is a moment of triumph, marking the beginning of a lifelong pride as a Six Star Finisher. To find out more about the World Marathon Majors, please  . The exact marathon distance is 26.2188 miles or 42.195 kilometers. But why?¬†The story starts over 2,000 years ago -  . The exact marathon distance is 26.2188 miles or 42.195 kilometers. But why? The story starts over 2,000 years ago in ancient Greece and takes in three key events before finishing in front of the Royal Family in 1908. According to an ancient Greek myth, in 490 BC the Athenian soldier Pheidippides was sent to Athens with a message to announce the Greek victory at the Battle of Marathon. The story goes that Pheidippides ran the   from the town of Marathon to Athens. Fast forward nearly 2,400 years to the first modern Olympic Games, held in Athens in 1896. A Frenchman called Michel Br√©al suggested to the organising committee that the Olympics should hold a running event that recreates Pheidippides' mythical journey. The idea was seized upon - they used the same route and named the event after the town where it all started. The marathon became a regular Olympic fixture - although each event was slightly different in length, they were still all roughly  . The 1908 Olympic Games organisers planned a   route from Windsor Castle to the entrance of the White City Stadium. However, to make it easier for the Royal Family to watch the start and finish, the race was started at Windsor Castle and finished in front of the royal box in the stadium - which added 385 yards to the original 26 mile route and that is why the exact marathon distance is now 26.2188 miles. In May 1921, the IAAF agreed to use the length used at the 1908 Olympics as the standard distance for the marathon and the rest, as they say, is history. The Boston Marathon is the world's oldest marathon and is regarded as one of the world's most prestigious events. It was first run on 19 April 1897 inspired by the marathon at the first modern Olympic Games in 1896 in Athens. The current world record for men is 2:00:35, set in the 2023 Chicago Marathon by Kelvin Kiptum of Kenya who died in a tragic car crash in 2024. The fastest female marathon runner is Tigist Assefa of Ethiopia who ran Berlin Marathon in 2:11:53 in 2023. Select your location for marathons in your area. Use the filters to find a multi-terrain run near you, or browse upcoming races across the UK.   Multi-terrain runs sit in the sweet spot between pure road races and full-on trail adventures. You‚Äôll often start on firm ground, dip onto tracks and paths, then switch back again‚Äîgreat for runners who want variety without committing to technical terrain all day. Because surfaces change, pacing changes too. Expect a more 'run smart' experience: steady effort, adaptable stride, and shoes that can handle a little of everything. Some events keep things friendly and fast with well-made paths, while others lean into rougher tracks for a bigger challenge. Scroll the listings, switch to map view, and use date and region filters to pick an event that matches your goal‚Äîfirst multi-terrain run, a confidence-building stepping stone to trail, or a fun race-day mix-up. Step 1 | Enter Choose your distance Step 1 | Enter Choose your distance Running Tribe events were borne out of the frustrations of founder Steve who, after completing 77 miles over 23 hours ended up walking away with nothing to show for his efforts after succumbing to an old injury. Running Tribe events are a bit different. Race training can be relentless but necessary to perform your very best on the day. You know you run better relaxed but sleep, nutrition and even that niggling injury all have to be in check too! In truth, there‚Äôs a lot that can get in the way of you finishing your full race distance. And when that happens, it‚Äôs gutting. Worse still, the distance you do manage to cover doesn‚Äôt count for anything. No medal, no congrats. Just the shame of handing over your number and slipping back to the car park empty-handed. Running Tribe thinks that‚Äôs wrong and are changing it, one race at a time. Running Tribe courses are circular routes of a minimum of 10.6k and you can attempt as many loops as you feel able to on the day. You‚Äôll have one of the best-stocked aid stations on the events circuit, packed with everything from baked goodies to energy gels and, as your kit bag will always within reasonable reach you can use your pitstop to test out different fuelling techniques and running gear along the way. Whether you manage to finish an ultra marathon, marathon, half or 10K, the distance you run will be celebrated, no matter what you set out to complete originally. That way, no matter what kept you up the night before, there‚Äôs still a reason to turn up and give it your everything. It‚Äôs short enough for beginners to enjoy, fast enough for experienced runners to push their pace and varied enough to offer something new each time you race. You‚Äôll find relaxed fun runs, charity events with big atmospheres, sharp PB-chasing routes and scenic off-road trails. Many events welcome runners of all abilities, with comfortable start waves and plenty of support along the route. If you‚Äôre chasing a time, look for flat road courses or evening runs designed for speed. If you‚Äôre after something different, trail 5Ks, night runs and themed events add an extra sense of adventure. Browse the full calendar or explore events in your region. Come and join the day of running and aim to complete a 5K at your own pace on an out-and-back route along an old railway line (quite flat) then receive a Rhino medal and goody bag at the finish! Brace yourself for this out-and-back course starting on the cliffs at Sewerby and running along the front at Bridlington. The course is great underfoot. Kick start your New Year resolutions with this popular New Year race which is returning to the historic town of Oundle! Enjoy the beautiful Northamptonshire countryside and the crisp winter air. Come and get involved in this Rise From The Ashes Run at The Last Hop in Staines, as long as you complete at least 3km you will be rewarded with one of the incredible phoenix medals! The Dark Skies returns for an undulating yomp through Surrey‚Äôs muddy, rolling hills in Dorking. A thrilling nighttime 5K trail race with canicross. Medal, branded kit and hot food available too. Enjoy a trip up the Leeds and Liverpool Canal this winter on your choice of distance, along the flat towpath for runners of all abilities, from novices to PB chasers! The route is exactly 5K, multi-terrain in nature, with a nice mix of minor road and trail to make for an interesting run in lovely surroundings, with fantastic views. Chip timing, prizes and medal! Run as far as you can during the 4-hour event through Brandon Country Park in the very heart of Thetford Forest on a multi-terrain loop. Run, rest, then head out for more. Happy New Year Run along the Leeds and Liverpool Canal with a choice of distances, all along the flat, even towpath. This event is perfect for runners of all abilities from novices to PB chasers! It's New Year! So what better way to start the year than with an event? Come to the Suffolk Running Centre and follow the Windmill Way route for 5K. Popular night-time trail races through Haldon Forest with beer, mince pies and medals for finishers! A range of distances to cater for all ages. Fun for all the family with fancy dress awards too. Storm the Fort 5K is the Gold award-winning event in the ‚ÄòDark Skies Series‚Äô of night trail running events, a three-event series taking part across Somerset. Gear up for an adrenaline-packed winter running experience like no other at Mallory Park Motor Racing Circuit! Come and join in Winter Lucky Dip Run, there is no set medal for this race, instead, you will get to choose your own from a selection of medals from past events! If you're looking to spice up your run or you need some running like you've never needed running before, then this is the event for you! Come and celebrate all things Spice Girls! Run as far as you can during the 4-hour event through the lovely Bawsey Country Park on a multi-terrain loop. Run, rest, then head out for more. Come and join in The Highland Hotfoot because who doesn't love those furry Highland Cows and therefore want a medal of them! Welcome to a 6-hour timed running event where you can run a 5K all the way up to an ultra marathon on an out-and-back route within the time limit, with fuel stations, medal and goody bag. The Moonlit Meadow Run 5K is a double Gold award-winning night trail running event and the original inspiration for the  ‚ÄòDark Skies Series‚Äô of three night trail running events across Somerset. Back to Ferry Meadows Country Park for another 4-hour running challenge! Run as much as you want through the forest on a multi-terrain loop. Run, rest, then head out for some more. A trail race event that is flat and fast and perfect for a PB and also brilliant for a beginner or the runner who wants to do their own pace with bespoke medal and treats at the finish line. Come and join the day of running and aim to complete a 5K at your own pace on an out-and-back route along an old railway line (nice and flat) then receive a medal and goody bag at the finish!

Explore ultra marathons across the UK, Europe and beyond from beginner-friendly single day events to brutal multi-day endurance challenges. Explore ultra runs across the UK ‚Äî from rugged trail epics to multi-hour endurance challenges. Whether you're stepping beyond the marathon for the first time or chasing your next long-distance adventure, use the filters to find events by date, location or terrain.   Taking on an ultra is a powerful step into the world of endurance running. Events push beyond the marathon distance and test stamina, pacing and grit across a huge variety of routes. You‚Äôll find everything from rolling countryside trails and coastal paths to brutal mountain courses that reward every mile with unforgettable views. Many ultras offer route choices, time-based challenges or multi-loop formats, making it easy to find something that matches your goals. If you're exploring your first ultra, shorter-distance events are an ideal introduction, while experienced runners can take on bigger point-to-point challenges, technical terrain or long-hours formats. Looking for a specific distance? Explore our dedicated hubs for  ,   and   to discover races suited to your experience level and training goals. Use the filters to narrow your search by date, location or route type ‚Äî and find your next all-day (or all-night) adventure. Want to read more? Read the   from our blog. Got questions?  . Discover ultramarathons near you and get ready for your next start line. Welcome to a 6-hour timed running event where you can run a 5K all the way up to an ultra marathon on an out-and-back route within the time limit, with fuel stations, Rhino medal and goody bag. Come and get involved in this Rise From The Ashes Run at The Last Hop in Staines, as long as you complete at least 3km you will be rewarded with one of the incredible phoenix medals! Looking for a challenge to get you out during the dull winter days and embrace the fine British weather? Run one ultra, or run both consecutive days, and circumnavigate the city of Leeds. A crisp morning start from the farm on a 50/50 road-trail mix with coastal views. Run a loop (a 'yard') every hour, on the hour, until only one runner remains. Miss the bell, and you're out. A fabulous 43-mile point-to-point race, well established as the season opener to the Ultra race calendar and always sells out. From the countryside along the Grand Union Canal into London. Enjoy a trip up the Leeds and Liverpool Canal this winter on your choice of distance, along the flat towpath for runners of all abilities, from novices to PB chasers! Happy New Year Run along the Leeds and Liverpool Canal with a choice of distances, all along the flat, even towpath. This event is perfect for runners of all abilities from novices to PB chasers! It's New Year! So what better way to start the year than with an ultra? Come to the Suffolk Running Centre and follow the Windmill Way route for over a marathon distance up to the 7-hour cut off. Come and get involved in this Rise From The Ashes Run in Durham, as long as you complete at least 5km you will be rewarded with one of the incredible phoenix medals! A great venue tucked away in the Warwickshire countryside. The ground is runnable all year and the views great too. Run as many 3.3-mile laps as you wish in the time limit, then receive your goodies! Come and join in Winter Lucky Dip Run, there is no set medal for this race, instead, you will get to choose your own from a selection of medals from past events! If you're looking to spice up your run or you need some running like you've never needed running before, then this is the event for you! Come and celebrate all things Spice Girls! A new and unique concept where you turn up ready to conquer an Ultra but if you feel like going easy, run a cool 1-3 loops instead! Ideal for testing out fuelling techniques & kit. A new and unique concept where you turn up ready to conquer an Ultra but if you feel like going easy, run a cool 1-3 loops instead! Ideal for testing out fuelling techniques & kit. A 48-mile route through historical Suffolk and Norfolk, starting from Knettishall Heath Nature reserve and running north to Holme-next-the-Sea on the Norfolk Coast. The reservoir has it all. The tranquillity of the woods, open grassland and calming waters, it‚Äôs a beauty! Run as many 3.3-mile loops as you like within 6 hours. Come and join in The Highland Hotfoot because who doesn't love those furry Highland Cows and therefore want a medal of them! Welcome to a 6-hour timed running event where you can run a 5K all the way up to an ultra marathon on an out-and-back route within the time limit, with fuel stations, medal and goody bag. Come and join The Racoon Rocket Run and earn yourself a beautiful medal with an adorable picture of a fluffy raccoon on it! What more could you ask for? Enjoy a trip up the Leeds and Liverpool Canal this Valentines. Perfect for runners of all abilities, from novices to Ultra PB chasers, this is one to warm the depths of your heart. Welcome to a 6-hour timed running event where you can run an ultra marathon at your own pace on an out-and-back route, with fuel stations each lap, and a Rhino medal and goody bag at the finish. Come and join in Smurf Run, who doesn't love those little blue characters and therefore a medal reflecting how adorable they are! Set along the beachfront promenade at Southbourne (SoBo), choose your own distance from 5K to ultra, along this flat, tarmacked, lapped route suitable for all abilities. For this run, not only will you earn a super cute rubber duck themed medal, but also your very own rubber ducky to take home with you! A new and unique concept where you turn up ready to conquer an Ultra Marathon but if you want to go easy, simply run a cool Marathon or Half Marathon, depending on how you feel on the day!

     Guides, tips and advice on running an ultra marathon. Introducing the 13 Valleys Ultra plus the event's shorter distance options, helping you to push your limits and get involved! To celebrate Global Running Day, we're rounding the best unsung marathons, half marathons and more in the UK!  Take on an epic endurance challenge with one of the most popular ultra runs in the UK, from traditional fell runs to the UTMB World Series! Ultra marathons are some of the greatest tests of endurance on the planet and yield unforgettable experiences - if you're well prepared. Answers to the most common questions about running an ultra marathon. Any running event longer than the marathon distance of 26.2 miles is classed as an ultra. Formats range from trail ultras and looped courses to long point-to-point challenges. Some ultras welcome first-timers, especially shorter-distance or looped formats. Others require experience due to technical terrain or long cut-off times. Always check the event details before entering. Many ultras take place on trails or mixed terrain, but some are run on roads or cycle paths. Use the filters to choose the surface and route style you prefer. Training time varies with distance and terrain, but most runners spend 12‚Äì20 weeks preparing for a shorter ultra and longer for more demanding events. Ultras often require items such as hydration packs, waterproof layers, head torches and nutrition supplies. Check the mandatory kit list for each event. Consider distance, elevation, terrain and cut-off times. If you're new to ultras, look at looped courses or shorter-distance events, or explore our   for beginner-friendly options. Select your location for ultra marathons in your area. A good night's sleep is an essential foundation for a healthy lifestyle, effective training and weight control. Low-intensity training is easier for you, reduces the risk of injury and helps builds an efficient aerobic system. Cut out sugar & junk food, reduce carbs, eat natural foods and train your body to burn fat for fuel. Fresh air, natural light and reconnecting with nature all help to improve mental and physical wellbeing. #FreeYourself ¬© Copyright. All rights reserved. A fabulous 43-mile point-to-point race, well established as the season opener to the Ultra race calendar and always sells out. From the countryside along the Grand Union Canal into London. 08:45 Age 18 & over ¬£80 If you are into ultra running, you need to have a crack at this race! It‚Äôs true to say that the always popular Country to Capital Ultra attracts a global field, with some of the best runners in Britain and beyond racing the 43-mile course. This famous race is the curtain raiser for the ultra running season ‚Äì and the starting point for those brave runners wishing to take on the Grand Slam of four ultra marathons over 180 gruelling miles. Country to Capital takes you through the Buckinghamshire countryside, crossing the M25 ‚Äì by bridge of course! ‚Äì and heading towards the well-heeled surroundings of Denham. From there, runners pick up the Grand Union Canal towpath for the final run into London. The finish is near the Little Venice canal basin, a surprisingly tranquil setting in the heart of the capital and close to both Paddington and Royal Oak Tube stations. The race concludes at The Stowe Centre, where you can enjoy showers, toilets and a large hall to relax in after finishing. Country to Capital is historically a sell-out event, so be sure to get your entry in early. It is fully tracked and interactive, allowing your friends and family to follow your progress from the comfort of their armchairs. You can also make sure that you are following the route correctly! Trail shoes mainly then change to road shoes at Denham Aerodrome/Denham Green Road if possible. A mandatory kit list is readily available. You can have your own crew. The golden rule is only do what would be possible for everyone else to do if they had a crew! Chesham (Germain Street), Chorleywood, Horn Hill (Dumb Bell Pub) and Denham Country Park. The route is displayed on the  Country to Capital is a 43 mile point to point Ultra Marathon starting at the Shoulder of Mutton Pub, Pound Street in Wendover and finishing at the Stowe Centre next to the Little Venice Canal basin close to London‚Äôs Paddington station and Royal Oak tube station. ¬†The route is a mix of country trails and canal towpath. A map book isn't provided but you have a tracker and the free voice navigation.¬† The route is 11.0 miles of cross country trails (26%); 12.1 miles of roads and paths (28%); and 20 miles of canal tow path (46%). Elevation is +1375 ft (419m) and -1720 ft (-524m). The course follows a waymarked route but requires some navigation. You will have an electronic tracker as standard which, with the app or webpage, will allow you to navigate the course with ease. Various resources will be provided to keep you on track. The course is covered by OS Maps 181, 172 and 173. There are 5 checkpoints. Each will have water, a selection of supplementary snacks and of course the famous fruit cake.¬† There are progressive cut off times from checkpoint 3 onwards. Details will be provided. Shoulder of Mutton 20 Pound Street Wendover Aylesbury Buckinghamshire HP22 6EJ UK For anyone wanting to stay overnight in Wendover either before or after the event there is Airbnb or the Red Lion Hotel. If you are planning to return to your car by train, parking is available in the station car park which is recommended. There is a public car park on the High Street (HP22 6DX) or surrounding on-street parking. There is no parking in the pub car park. The train from Marylebone usually arrives just before 8:30am so you will need to arrive ready to run and you will be processed through registration in time for the 8:45am start. Prizes will be awarded for 1st, 2nd and 3rd Male and Female Competitors.¬† The tracker provided was brilliant, I had family and friends, even those not very good with technology able to follow along :) makes it much more enjoyable for everyone, the pub at the start is warm and cosy, ideal for a coffee and pre race bib checks etc, portaloos in the pubs rear car park with clean and stocked, no complaints. Alex F Great course, event, organization. Chris K This is an excellent race. The team running it are fantastic and look after the runners exceptionally well. The race is unmarked, which can be a put off for some, but the supplied GPX is perfect and there are few places where people get lost. The amount of veterans who do the race year on year helps a lot too. The medal this year was exceptional, and the event aims to give something useful in place of a t-shirt. This year it was a snood, last year armwarmers. Crispin K Great course and was well looked after at the checkpoints no complaints from me I look forward to next year! Peter V Very well run event. Was nervous about the navigation but it was very easy. Luke V Absolutely loved it again, quicker than last year as a bonus. Cannot fault the race one bit, even when my race number was issued to someone else it was sorted quick and with no fuss. I will be back next year. Peter H Absolutely fantastic event with seamless organisation! Jack M My sixth year running this event! Always a great start to the year. Brilliantly organised, nice varied course with a great mixture of terrain. I'd recommend this race to anyone, seasoned Ultras of first timers alike. Jim W Another well organised and supported race. If you're into Ultra running then you need to have a crack at this race, a real mix of terrain to challenge your physical ability and mindset. Friendly support staff, decent aid stations, well marked challenging course. Trev C Reviews thanks to RaceCheck Add the event to your shortlist to make it easy to find again. Round Two at Dover kicks off on a crisp winter morning. It is your chance to find out what you‚Äôre really capable of ‚Äî not in a blaze of glory, but one quiet hour at a time. This is the first of four rounds in the Kent Backyard Ultra Series: Each round is a new challenge. Whether you‚Äôre after farmer‚Äôs fields, dry gravel tracks, or forest trails, there's something for you. You can have a small crew with you at the event base to assist between loops (food, kit, encouragement, tough love, etc.). Just keep it low-key ‚Äî space is limited, and this isn‚Äôt Glastonbury. Crew aren‚Äôt allowed to pace you or provide outside assistance on the course ‚Äî only at base between yards. Night running can feel intimidating ‚Äî especially if you‚Äôre arriving solo. So here‚Äôs how it will be safer, more welcoming, and better supported for everyone: Farthingloe Barn Folkestone Road Dover Kent CT15 7AA UK 09:00 Age 16 & over ¬£73-¬£75 09:00 Age 16 & over ¬£113-¬£115 Add the event to your shortlist to make it easy to find again. Take on a tough, award-winning trail run in the Surrey Hills and North Downs with a cracking sunrise, stop-in-your-tracks views and five-star reviews! No nonsense trail running. 08:00 Age 15 & over ¬£27 08:00 Age 16 & over ¬£31 There will be hills, mud, rocks, sand, forest and outstanding views. You will need your trail shoes. Love the G3 series. Really well organised and truly stunning courses. Trail shoes. Newlands Corner Drove Road Albury Guildford Surrey GU4 8SE UK Follow the parking marshals instructions once in the car park. It was my fourth time completing the series, and I always look forward to next year. The course has amazing views, is challenging, and has brilliant marshals and organisation. Top marks! Isabella K The perfect races. No nonsense, great crowd, courses, locations and well organised. Back home by 10! Anthony A Love the G3 series. Really well organised and truly stunning courses, shame about the hills though üòÑ . I will look forward to them in 2026! Emma W Love the G3 races! Always a highlight of the race calendar and always puts a smile on my face. The courses are challenging and will give you a good workout. Well-organised, friendly event with no frills. I recommend it if you‚Äôre looking for a fun winter trail race. Mike B This was my 1st G3 run at this venue, and I was expecting the 10km to include more hills, but was very relieved that it didn't. The single very steep one (that I can't forget) was enough. Enjoyed the run along the stream to wash the mud off, even though it was a bit fresh at this time of year. Great route! Great team! Looking forward to doing it all over again. Kyra C Fabulous event. Friendly, well-organised and great route. Fiona A I hate hills and early mornings, so I have no idea why I torture myself with this series. There's just something about slopping through mud, paddling through a river and giving oneself a migraine with the focus required to stay upright on the downhills.üòÜ If you're REALLY lucky, you will be next to a foreigner at the bottom of a steep incline and learn some norty words in a new language. Don't change a thing. Diane L Fantastic event with a brilliant mix of mud/hills/rocky trail/ splashing around. I had a blast and the whole event was smoothly run, well marshalling and signposted. All finished with delicious brownies and bananas. Can‚Äôt get any better to start the weekend, I‚Äôll be back. Katie A What an amazing race, beautiful scenery, really challenged me, but loved it. This was my first event here, definitely returning. Miss V Been doing this series for a few years now, it is a great local event. Course is challenging, Marshall‚Äôs are great looking forward to the next one already. No nonsense trail running. 08:00 Age 15 & over ¬£27 There will be hills, mud, rocks, sand, forest and outstanding views. You will need your trail shoes. Love the G3 series. Really well organised and truly stunning courses. This event is part of  . Trail shoes. There will be hills, a cracking sunrise and ‚Äòstop you in your tracks‚Äô views, mud, rocks, sand and forest - the very best that the Surrey Hills can throw at you! There are tricky descents and some road crossings. There are usually road crossings so always be mindful of cars. Volunteer marshals will be there to make sure you‚Äôre checking it‚Äôs safe to cross. Horses and cyclists: Always be aware of both. If approaching horses from behind, make yourself known in good time to avoid unwanted surprises! Hound House Road Guildford Surrey GU5 9JG UK Follow the parking marshals instructions once in the car park. It was my fourth time completing the series, and I always look forward to next year. The course has amazing views, is challenging, and has brilliant marshals and organisation. Top marks! Isabella K The perfect races. No nonsense, great crowd, courses, locations and well organised. Fiona A I hate hills and early mornings, so I have no idea why I torture myself with this series. The Eggcellent Easter Pink Run is the second event in the five-day series where you can earn the fantastic easter egg medal in pink! The Eggcellent Easter Green Run is the third event in the five-day series where you can earn the fantastic easter egg medal in green! raw.full_description: Don‚Äôt start another race feeling under pressure. Sign up for a Running Tribe event today, relax and run your own race. Don‚Äôt start another race feeling under pressure. Sign up for a Running Tribe event today, relax and run your own race. Step 1 | Enter Choose your distance Step 1 | Enter Choose your distance Running Tribe events were borne out of the frustrations of founder Steve who, after completing 77 miles over 23 hours ended up walking away with nothing to show for his efforts after succumbing to an old injury. Running Tribe events are a bit different. Race training can be relentless but necessary to perform your very best on the day. You know you run better relaxed but sleep, nutrition and even that niggling injury all have to be in check too! In truth, there‚Äôs a lot that can get in the way of you finishing your full race distance. And when that happens, it‚Äôs gutting. Worse still, the distance you do manage to cover doesn‚Äôt count for anything. No medal, no congrats. Just the shame of handing over your number and slipping back to the car park empty-handed. Running Tribe thinks that‚Äôs wrong and are changing it, one race at a time. Running Tribe courses are circular routes of a minimum of 10.6k and you can attempt as many loops as you feel able to on the day. You‚Äôll have one of the best-stocked aid stations on the events circuit, packed with everything from baked goodies to energy gels and, as your kit bag will always within reasonable reach you can use your pitstop to test out different fuelling techniques and running gear along the way. Whether you manage to finish an ultra marathon, marathon, half or 10K, the distance you run will be celebrated, no matter what you set out to complete originally. That way, no matter what kept you up the night before, there‚Äôs still a reason to turn up and give it your everything. The Kirkstall Bridge 10K is a fast, flat, out-and-back canal run suitable for all runners, with a cosy, warm atmosphere at the pub afterwards. 11:00 Age 18 & over ¬£20 Choose betwen a 16km trail race taking in the sights of the fantastic Leeds Liverpool Canal, River Aire and the brutal Calverley Cutting, or the shorter Kirkstall Bridge 10km, which is a fast, flat, out-and-back canal run suitable for all runners. Race registration takes place at the award-winning Kirkstall Bridge, for that cosy, warm atmosphere after what will certainly be a very cold January race! Although the route is relatively simple, the course will be fully marked and marshalled at key areas. The race will start just a hop away from the pub on the Leeds Liverpool Canal. It is also becoming a tradition to do the Kirkstall Calverley Cutter after Parkrun! Due to the ongoing flood relief works along the River Aire we may need to divert the course slightly. This will be decided close to the race date. This event is part of  . A mandatory kit list is available. The route is displayed on the  Canal towpath, riverside trails and public footpaths. Take in the sights of the fantastic Leeds Liverpool Canal, River Aire and the brutal Calverley Cutting on a fast, flat, canal run. Kirkstall Bridge Inn 12 Bridge Road Leeds West Yorkshire LS5 3BW UK Due to works on the River Aire, The Bridge Pub is currently unable to deal with large amounts of cars so will be limited to staff, pub patrons and medical personnel only. There is on-street parking nearby so please park locally and sensibly. Please avoid Morrisons and Kirkstall retail park (customers only max stay 2hrs). Please lift share when possible. Please cycle to the event as there are plenty of places to lock your bike close to the venue.¬† The Nearest Train Station is Headingley and is about 800m away. My second appearance at the Kirkstall Calverley Cutter. Adam and his willing team of volunteers are fantastic, nothing is too much trouble. The route has a bit of everything that I‚Äôm sure appeals to others too. The registration process at The Bridge Inn Kirkstall, works very efficiently. The finish area is in the pub car park, giving you an added incentive to run faster and come back to enjoy the post race hospitality. Would recommend this race to others, 100%. See you next January. Rick H Amazing course and support, everything was top-notch. Can‚Äôt wait to race again next year! Jessica B The course was perfectly marked, and the entire event was flawlessly managed. Highly recommended! Rebecca S Well-organised and run. Course was pleasant and straightforward. Nothing more to say other than I would recommend, cheers! Jack M One of the best races I‚Äôve ever done. Incredible energy and great support! Sol B Great low key event starting and finishing in a pub - what's not to like? Nice route with nice people üëå Matt H Great atmosphere, very well marked route! If you are going to start your adventure with trail running, this is a great choice. 16 km is not just a distance - it is the beginning of the path to perseverance, passion and discovering your limits. Every step to 16 km is a journey into yourself... Tomasz S Really enjoyed this one - flat, fast, friendly. Cups of water ready to drink might help. Rob D It was a great event, well organised and promoted. We started a little later than advertised but it wasn‚Äôt a problem. The finish was a bit blocked up and the time keeper struggled to see the finishers as they came through. Also little warning about a local living on a narrow boat who wasn‚Äôt best pleased about the traffic and complained to runners.
